articles.headline: Ethiopia and Tigray Forces Agree to Truce in Calamitous Civil War
articles.snippet: After two years of fighting that left hundreds of thousands dead and millions displaced and facing starvation, the surprise deal came out of peace talks convened by the African Union in South Africa.
articles.abstract: After two years of fighting that left hundreds of thousands dead and millions displaced and facing starvation, the surprise deal came out of peace talks convened by the African Union in South Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: After two years of brutal civil war, the Ethiopian government and the leadership of the northern Tigray region agreed to stop fighting on Wednesday as part of a deal that offered a path out of a conflict that has killed hundreds of thousands and displaced millions in Africa’s second-most-populous country.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh, Abdi Latif Dahir and Lynsey Chutel

articles.headline: Elon Musk Takes a Page Out of Mark Zuckerberg’s Social Media Playbook
articles.snippet: As Mr. Musk takes over Twitter, he is emulating some of the actions of Mr. Zuckerberg, who leads Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp.
articles.abstract: As Mr. Musk takes over Twitter, he is emulating some of the actions of Mr. Zuckerberg, who leads Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has positioned himself as an unconventional businessman. When he agreed to buy Twitter this year, he declared he would make the social media service a place for unfettered free speech, reversing many of its rules and allowing banned users like former President Donald J. Trump to return.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger, Ryan Mac and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Bank of England Sees Recession Ahead, but Raises Rates Most Since 1989
articles.snippet: With inflation above 10 percent, the central bank ramped up its fight against price increases even as it predicted a “prolonged” recession.
articles.abstract: With inflation above 10 percent, the central bank ramped up its fight against price increases even as it predicted a “prolonged” recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Bank of England intensified its battle against inflation on Thursday, raising interest rates by the largest amount since 1989, even as it predicted that the British economy would enter a “prolonged” recession.

articles.headline: Mortgage Rates Too High? (Blame the Fed, Wall Street and Your Neighbor.)
articles.snippet: Lenders use several bits of data to set mortgage rates, including trading moves by investors. Without market volatility, the rate could be under 7 percent.
articles.abstract: Lenders use several bits of data to set mortgage rates, including trading moves by investors. Without market volatility, the rate could be under 7 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mila Adams moved to Utah in May with her husband and toddler son to be closer to family, but they didn’t expect to be living with her husband’s parents nearly a half year later.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: China Is Burning More Coal, a Growing Climate Challenge
articles.snippet: The country’s emissions of greenhouse gases rose last year at the fastest pace in a decade. Beijing is looking for alternatives.
articles.abstract: The country’s emissions of greenhouse gases rose last year at the fastest pace in a decade. Beijing is looking for alternatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: China is poised to take advantage of the global urgency to tackle climate change. It is the world’s dominant manufacturer and user of solar panels and wind turbines. It leads the world in producing energy from hydroelectric dams and is building more nuclear power plants than any other country.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Cherokees Ask U.S. to Make Good on a 187-Year-Old Promise, for a Start
articles.snippet: The demand that Congress honor a treaty and seat a nonvoting delegate comes amid growing clashes over sovereignty and a tight race for Oklahoma’s governor, a Cherokee citizen.
articles.abstract: The demand that Congress honor a treaty and seat a nonvoting delegate comes amid growing clashes over sovereignty and a tight race for Oklahoma’s governor, a Cherokee citizen.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAHLEQUAH, Okla. — In 1835, U.S. officials traveled to the Cherokee Nation’s capital in Georgia to sign a treaty forcing the Cherokees off their lands in the American South, opening them to white settlers. The Treaty of New Echota sent thousands on a death march to new lands in Oklahoma.

articles.headline: Lapid Concedes in Israel, Paving Way for Netanyahu’s Return to Power
articles.snippet: After five elections in less than four years, Israel will have a stable government for the first time since 2019. But Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition could test the constitutional framework and social fabric.
articles.abstract: After five elections in less than four years, Israel will have a stable government for the first time since 2019. But Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition could test the constitutional framework and social fabric.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — He lost power in Israel a year ago under a cloud of corruption charges and political dysfunction. But on Thursday, Benjamin Netanyahu cemented his return to the prime minister’s post that he has held for longer than any other Israeli leader.
